Pick your movie of the week: Bad Star Wars (June 6-12/21)

Actors From Around the World

Most of us are well versed on who the most famous actors are from Canada and the US, but how about the rest of the world? Here are some actors and a couple of directors who are (arguably) the most famous from their respective countries. All but one were born in the country in question. If there is anyone I missed who should be on this, either because their country has no one attached to it or because they’re more famous than who I have there, please feel free to let me know.

Joonas Suotamo (FINLAND) — Famous for playing Chewbacca in Star Wars episodes 8, 9 (a double in 7) and in Solo: A Star Wars Story (2018)

I know what you’re thinking, and yes, this did take me forever to do. However, I enjoy working on this blog. I find it relaxing and fun. So, perhaps I should invoke Captain Corelli in this week’s best quote: “…and for that I cannot apologize.”

Chasing Amy

Turns out Amy Adams is a much more interesting person than I had thought. Here are some things you may or may not have known about this outstanding actress:

Once when boarding a flight in Detroit headed for LA she found out that there was an American soldier also booked on the flight. She had a first class ticket while he had coach. She privately requested to switch seats with him as a gesture of appreciation to the US troops.

According to IMDb her ancestry is mainly English, though she has “smaller amounts” of Danish, Swiss-German, Norwegian, Welsh, German, Irish, Scottish, and Scots-Irish/Northern Irish. That and she grew up in Colorado. Oh, and she was born in Italy.

She’s been with the same man for the past 20 years, Darren Le Gallo. They met in an acting class, started dating, got engaged in 2008, and have an 11-year-old daughter, Aviana Olea.

She revealed in a red carpet interview one year that she suffers from a terrible stage fright.

She did all her own singing in Enchanted (2007), The Muppets (2011), and Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2007). I don’t remember seeing her dance in any of her movies, but she is a trained dancer, too.

She grew up in a Mormon family. She doesn’t share the beliefs today, though she says it influenced her values. Unfortunately she also often struggles with unnecessary guilt from time to time as a result as well.

She acted in two movies with Meryl Streep, and they were back to back: Doubt (2008) and Julie and Julia (2009). Somewhere during that time Streep taught her how to knit.

Have you ever gotten Amy Adams confused with Isla Fisher? If so, you’re not alone. Fisher’s husband, Sacha Baron Cohen, is a constant prankster. One year when the family sent out Christmas cards to friends and family, he pasted Amy Adams’ face over his wife’s. The card read, “Season Greetings from Sacha, Isla and the Kids.” And apparently no one noticed!

Most of us recognize Enchanted as her breakthrough film, and it really was. But her role in Junebug (2005) was the one that got her there. You may not have seen that one (I haven’t…), but her performance got everyone’s attention. It was an unassuming low budget movie, but Adams’ performance stole the show, and earned her an Oscar nomination that year.

She has starred in five films nominated for Best Picture at the Oscars. She has also been nominated for an Oscar 6 times for her acting. And the longest she’s gone without an acting nomination since 2006 is 5 years.

Despite this, she has definitely been snubbed by the Academy. There are only 8 actors who have been denied an Oscar nomination while being nominated by the Golden Globes, BAFTA, SAG, and Critic’s Choice Awards for the same role. Amy is one of them, for her role in Arrival (2016).

She’s had some pretty deep existential crises when attending those Oscar ceremonies. One time she was sitting between Meryl Streep and Sean Penn and thought to herself, “What am I doing here? I don’t belong here!” And then there was the year she was singing at the ceremony. She said in an interview that it was nerve-wracking to be singing in front of billions of people, noting that this included Daniel Day-Lewis and Cate Blanchett. Her solution that night was to go to Taco Bell. Mexican food, she declared, heals her.

Her best friend is her former co-star in Sunshine Cleaning (2008), Emily Blunt.

She and Leonardo DiCaprio played teenage lovers in Catch Me If You Can (2002), which is interesting for two reasons: 1) they were both 28 at the time, and 2) she had a crush on him for a short time as a teenager when seeing him playing a small role on the TV show Growing Pains.

Congratulations Amy Adams and Arrival. This is your week.

And the Oscar goes to…

Best Actor: Jeremy Renner as Ian Donnelly in Arrival

If Canada Changed Its Flag

Remember in 2017 when we celebrated Canada being 150 years old? During that time some of the Indigenous people of our country said they would refrain from the festivities because they didn’t see this country as being that young. They argued that 150 years just marks an anniversary of a year that something was made official: that this land was no longer theirs. It must seem ironic to hear the national anthems words “our home and native land.”

This got me thinking that year… Would it bother me if a declaration was made that from now on as a country we would continue to celebrate our country, but not confederation? And in that vein, what if more things were changed, things that I often equate with Canadian identity? Would I mind if our flag was changed or replaced entirely? Would I mind if the House of Commons was made up of 20% white Anglophones and Francophones, the rest made up of Indigenous and immigrated nationalities?

As a teenager I had a Canadian flag hanging on my bedroom wall. As an adult I lived in a foreign land as a missionary for 4 years: the United States (Trying to convert the savages there wasn’t easy!). Everyone there knew I was Canadian because I constantly told them about how great our country is. To this day, whenever I experience a sickness, accident, or some unfortunate event (like, say, a global pandemic), one of my first thoughts is, “This sucks, but I’m sure glad I’m going through this here in Canada.”

I’ve always seen myself as a proud Canadian. But I’m not tied to anything a group of entitled people who were fortunate enough to win a war declare as Canadian, especially if there was any trace of inhumanity in their actions. It is the land and the people in it that matter to me.

If we grew as a people and recognized our diversity, true history, and true identity to the point that we changed our flag, our official language(s), our observances, and the content of our history books, I think I would be totally ok with that. We are Canada. No blind patriotism, just true patriot love.

Our nominees this week represented the Maritime provinces, the best part of Canada. In writing this post I am hoping that news of our existence gets leaked to Ontario!

Animated Movies that Could Have Won

2001’s Shrek has the distinction of being the first movie to receive the “Best Animated Feature” Academy Award. Up to that point, only animated shorts won Oscars, which seems crazy. Classics like The Little Mermaid (1989) and Bambi (1942) could win in categories like music, but The Wrong Trousers (1993) and The Crunch Bird (1971) would get the recognition of being the best of the year.

So I thought this would be fun: If the Oscars had “best animated feature award” from 1939 and on, here’s who I think would win each year…

NOTE: Obviously this was difficult for some years. 5 Years Later: Was Oscar So White?

Five to six years ago people of colour in the entertainment business began to protest that there was not enough representation in the Academy Awards. What sparked this was that for two consecutive years the Academy gave all 20 acting nomination slots to white actors. In the entertainment world, many were expecting at least Will Smith to be nominated for Concussion (2015), but wasn’t. The protest was called #OscarSoWhite, and most of us with lighter skin were feeling skeptical of it. I mean, the awards should be based on who the best actors were and not on skin colour, right? But then something happened after the 2016 Oscars.

13th, Moonlight, Straight Out of Compton, Birth of a Nation, Fences, I am Not Your Negro, Get Out, Mudbound, If Beale Street Could Talk, BlacKkKlansman, Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse, Dolemite is My Name, Black Panther, Antebellum, The United States vs Billie Holliday, One Night in Miami, Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom and many others. All having either a cast predominantly made up of persons of colour, a focus on culture or issues pertaining to people of colour, or both. They are all also movies that have received both critical and commercial acclaim. So this means that any of the following has happened:

Hollywood is forcing it. The argument here is that the movie industry buckled under the pressure of actors of colour. They wanted to be relevant and prove they are not racists and made these movies with these cast members, passing on other scripts and casts. BUT: So many directors, producers, actors, and critics have expressed admiration for these films. And before we argue that those very people are Hollywood, the same can be said of regular ol’ movie goers. I’ve seen all but one of the movies listed above, and I can’t say I loved them all, of course. But I can say that collectively they are as good as any other stack of movies that have received Oscar nominations throughout the past decade. I mean, it’s honestly an impressive list of films. You have to wonder: Were these all forced on us by Hollywood, and by coincidence there just happens to be a significant amount of them that are good enough to get the recognition they get? Or… was Oscar really so white? Were the protesters right and are these films the proof?

It’s just happening naturally. We’ve always had significant movies like this. Consider The Help (2011), Do the Right Thing (1989), Precious (2009), Remember the Titans (2000), The Color Purple (1985), Glory (1989), and many others. They were always movies like this being made, and every decade sees more than the previous. We’ve naturally grown into our diversity. However… again… isn’t this a rather large coincidence that this natural growth seemed to take such a significant jump right after 2016’s #OscarSoWhite? I mean, it’s hard to find any two decades in the past that together can even compete with the last 5 years.

#OscarSoWhtie was right. You’ve likely guessed that this is how I see it. No, the actors and directors of colour were not asking to be awarded based on their skin colour. They were simply wanting to not be overlooked or counted out because of it. They could see the systemic racism that was happening. This was not intended to take anything away from the white actors and actresses who’d been nomination recipients in the past. They were all deserving. No one is taking anything away from them. But if people are being overlooked because of their colour, even if it’s subconscious, then we’re getting neither a fair nor accurate picture of the achievements from of each year.

I have to admit here that it does feel weird making these arguments. I feel like a privileged white guy “whitesplaining” a movement led by people of colour in an industry I know so little about. And I might just be that. But I can honestly say that I am only trying to share what I have observed as a movie fan and what I sincerely think/feel/believe is happening. As I’ve shared before, trying to understand other people’s perspectives is a strongly held value of mine. We cannot adequately love one another without adequately understanding one another.

Congratulations In the Heat of the Night. This is your week.
